verses.text: Praise the Lord from the heavens; praise Him in the heights above.
verses.comment: The psalm begins with a call to praise that starts in the heavenly realms. This sets the tone for the universal praise due to God, reflecting both the transcendence and immanence of the Lord.

verses.text: Praise Him, all His angels; praise Him, all His hosts.
verses.comment: The angelic hosts are called to praise God, a reminder of the created order in heaven serving and worshiping God perpetually. The angelic praise is a model for earthly worship.

verses.text: Praise Him, sun and moon; praise Him, all you shining stars.
verses.comment: Even the heavenly bodies are summoned to worship, symbolizing all creation's participation in giving glory to its Creator. This points to the sacramental nature of creation: visible signs revealing invisible truths.

verses.text: Praise Him, you highest heavens, and you waters above the skies.
verses.comment: There is a reference here to creation’s structure. The poetic inclusion of ‘waters above’ recalls the Genesis creation account, hinting at God’s sovereignty over every aspect of reality, both seen and unseen.

verses.text: Let them praise the name of the Lord, for He commanded and they were created.
verses.comment: All creation owes its existence to God’s Word. This illustrates the power of divine command (‘He commanded and they were created’), an idea echoed in John 1:1 where Christ is revealed as the Word through whom all things were made.

verses.text: And He established them forever and ever; He gave a decree, and it shall not pass away.
verses.comment: God’s laws of nature are enduring and fixed. The notion of God's decrees sustaining creation has spiritual meaning too: God’s covenant promises endure as do the laws of creation.

verses.text: Praise the Lord from the earth, you great sea creatures and all ocean depths,
verses.comment: The praise of God is not confined to the heavens; the earth and its wonders are called to worship. This includes even the mysterious depths, illustrating the fullness of God's glory in all realms.

verses.text: Fire and hail, snow and clouds; stormy wind fulfilling His command;
verses.comment: All weather phenomena are portrayed as obedient to God's will. Even forces that seem chaotic are under divine command, showing God’s providential authority over the natural world.

verses.text: Mountains and all hills, fruit trees and all cedars;
verses.comment: The physical features of the earth and its vegetation are called to join the chorus of praise. Throughout Scripture, mountains often represent places of divine encounter, and trees are symbols of life and blessing.

verses.text: Wild animals and all livestock, crawling creatures and flying birds;
verses.comment: The diversity of living creatures is included in the call to glorify God. This universality mirrors the ultimate reconciliation of all things to God, as described in Colossians 1:19-20.

verses.text: Kings of the earth and all peoples, princes and all judges of the earth,
verses.comment: The call extends to every human authority, affirming that even the most powerful require humility before God. This anticipates the role of leaders in upholding justice and worship, a motif fulfilled in God's kingdom.

verses.text: Young men and young women, old men and children together—
verses.comment: All people, regardless of age or status, are invited to praise. This reflects the inclusive call to worship that finds its fullness in the communal worship of the Church, transcending generations.

verses.text: Let them praise the name of the Lord, for His name alone is exalted; His majesty is above earth and heaven.
verses.comment: The unique transcendence of God is emphasized here. God’s name, a sign of His divine presence and authority, stands above all. This is foundational for understanding worship and reverence in the Christian tradition.

verses.text: He has raised up a horn for His people, praise for all His faithful, for the people of Israel, the people close to Him. Praise the Lord!
verses.comment: ‘Horn’ is a symbol of strength and salvation, anticipating the messianic hope fulfilled in Jesus (see Luke 1:69). Israel’s close relationship to God is spiritualized in the Church, composed of the faithful who are brought near by redemption through Christ.
